trans-unit.source: How to use Service Bus topics (PHP) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use Service Bus topics (PHP) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Service Bus topics with PHP in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Service Bus topics with PHP in Azure.

trans-unit.source: How to use Service Bus topics and subscriptions
trans-unit.target: How to use Service Bus topics and subscriptions

trans-unit.source: This guide shows you how to use Service Bus topics and subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: This guide shows you how to use Service Bus topics and subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: The samples are written in PHP and use the <link><linkText>Azure SDK for PHP</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: The samples are written in PHP and use the <link><linkText>Azure SDK for PHP</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include creating topics and subscriptions, creating subscription filters, sending messages to a topic, receiving messages from a subscription, and deleting topics and subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include creating topics and subscriptions, creating subscription filters, sending messages to a topic, receiving messages from a subscription, and deleting topics and subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: Create a PHP application
trans-unit.target: Create a PHP application

trans-unit.source: The only requirement for creating a PHP application that accesses the Azure Blob service is the referencing of classes in the <link><linkText>Azure SDK for PHP</linkText><title></title></link> from within your code.
trans-unit.target: The only requirement for creating a PHP application that accesses the Azure Blob service is the referencing of classes in the <link><linkText>Azure SDK for PHP</linkText><title></title></link> from within your code.

trans-unit.source: You can use any development tools to create your application, or Notepad.
trans-unit.target: You can use any development tools to create your application, or Notepad.

trans-unit.source: Your PHP installation must also have the <link><linkText>OpenSSL extension</linkText><title></title></link> installed and enabled.
trans-unit.target: Your PHP installation must also have the <link><linkText>OpenSSL extension</linkText><title></title></link> installed and enabled.

trans-unit.source: In this guide, you will use service features which can be called within a PHP application locally, or in code running within an Azure web role, worker role, or website.
trans-unit.target: In this guide, you will use service features which can be called within a PHP application locally, or in code running within an Azure web role, worker role, or website.

trans-unit.source: Get the Azure client libraries
trans-unit.target: Get the Azure client libraries

trans-unit.source: Configure your application to use Service Bus
trans-unit.target: Configure your application to use Service Bus

trans-unit.source: To use the Service Bus APIs:
trans-unit.target: To use the Service Bus APIs:

trans-unit.source: Reference the autoloader file using the <link><linkText>require_once[require-once]</linkText><title></title></link> statement.
trans-unit.target: Reference the autoloader file using the <link><linkText>require_once[require-once]</linkText><title></title></link> statement.

trans-unit.source: Reference any classes you might use.
trans-unit.target: Reference any classes you might use.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to include the autoloader file and reference the ServiceBusService class.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to include the autoloader file and reference the ServiceBusService class.

trans-unit.source: This example (and other examples in this article) assumes you have installed the PHP Client Libraries for Azure via Composer.
trans-unit.target: This example (and other examples in this article) assumes you have installed the PHP Client Libraries for Azure via Composer.

trans-unit.source: If you installed the libraries manually or as a PEAR package, you must reference the WindowsAzure.php autoloader file.
trans-unit.target: If you installed the libraries manually or as a PEAR package, you must reference the WindowsAzure.php autoloader file.

trans-unit.source: In the examples below, the require_once statement will always be shown, but only the classes necessary for the example to execute are referenced.
trans-unit.target: In the examples below, the require_once statement will always be shown, but only the classes necessary for the example to execute are referenced.

trans-unit.source: Set up a Service Bus connection
trans-unit.target: Set up a Service Bus connection

trans-unit.source: To instantiate an Azure Service Bus client you must first have a valid connection string in this format:
trans-unit.target: To instantiate an Azure Service Bus client you must first have a valid connection string in this format:

trans-unit.source: Where Endpoint is typically of the format https://[yourNamespace].servicebus.windows.net.
trans-unit.target: Where Endpoint is typically of the format https://[yourNamespace].servicebus.windows.net.

trans-unit.source: To create any Azure service client you must use the ServicesBuilder class.
trans-unit.target: To create any Azure service client you must use the ServicesBuilder class.

trans-unit.source: You can:
trans-unit.target: You can:

trans-unit.source: Pass the connection string directly to it.
trans-unit.target: Pass the connection string directly to it.

trans-unit.source: Use the CloudConfigurationManager (CCM) to check multiple external sources for the connection string:
trans-unit.target: Use the CloudConfigurationManager (CCM) to check multiple external sources for the connection string:

trans-unit.source: By default it comes with support for one external source - environmental variables.
trans-unit.target: By default it comes with support for one external source - environmental variables.

trans-unit.source: You can add new sources by extending the ConnectionStringSource class.
trans-unit.target: You can add new sources by extending the ConnectionStringSource class.

trans-unit.source: For the examples outlined here, the connection string will be passed directly.
trans-unit.target: For the examples outlined here, the connection string will be passed directly.

trans-unit.source: How to: create a topic
trans-unit.target: How to: create a topic

trans-unit.source: Management operations for Service Bus topics can be performed via the ServiceBusRestProxy class.
trans-unit.target: Management operations for Service Bus topics can be performed via the ServiceBusRestProxy class.

trans-unit.source: A ServiceBusRestProxy object is constructed via the ServicesBuilder::createServiceBusService factory method with an appropriate connection string that encapsulates the token permissions to manage it.
trans-unit.target: A ServiceBusRestProxy object is constructed via the ServicesBuilder::createServiceBusService factory method with an appropriate connection string that encapsulates the token permissions to manage it.

trans-unit.source: The example below shows how to instantiate a ServiceBusRestProxy and call ServiceBusRestProxy->createTopic to create a topic named mytopic within a MySBNamespace service namespace:
trans-unit.target: The example below shows how to instantiate a ServiceBusRestProxy and call ServiceBusRestProxy->createTopic to create a topic named mytopic within a MySBNamespace service namespace:

trans-unit.source: You can use the listTopics method on ServiceBusRestProxy objects to check if a topic with a specified name already exists within a service namespace.
trans-unit.target: You can use the listTopics method on ServiceBusRestProxy objects to check if a topic with a specified name already exists within a service namespace.

trans-unit.source: How to: create a subscription
trans-unit.target: How to: create a subscription

trans-unit.source: Topic subscriptions are also created with the ServiceBusRestProxy->createSubscription method.
trans-unit.target: Topic subscriptions are also created with the ServiceBusRestProxy->createSubscription method.

trans-unit.source: Subscriptions are named and can have an optional filter that restricts the set of messages passed to the subscription's virtual queue.
trans-unit.target: Subscriptions are named and can have an optional filter that restricts the set of messages passed to the subscription's virtual queue.

trans-unit.source: Create a subscription with the default (MatchAll) filter
trans-unit.target: Create a subscription with the default (MatchAll) filter

trans-unit.source: The MatchAll filter is the default filter that is used if no filter is specified when a new subscription is created.
trans-unit.target: The MatchAll filter is the default filter that is used if no filter is specified when a new subscription is created.

trans-unit.source: When the MatchAll filter is used, all messages published to the topic are placed in the subscription's virtual queue.
trans-unit.target: When the MatchAll filter is used, all messages published to the topic are placed in the subscription's virtual queue.

trans-unit.source: The following example creates a subscription named 'mysubscription' and uses the default MatchAll filter.
trans-unit.target: The following example creates a subscription named 'mysubscription' and uses the default MatchAll filter.

trans-unit.source: Create subscriptions with filters
trans-unit.target: Create subscriptions with filters

trans-unit.source: You can also set up filters that enable you to specify which messages sent to a topic should show up within a specific topic subscription.
trans-unit.target: You can also set up filters that enable you to specify which messages sent to a topic should show up within a specific topic subscription.

trans-unit.source: The most flexible type of filter supported by subscriptions is the SqlFilter, which implements a subset of SQL92.
trans-unit.target: The most flexible type of filter supported by subscriptions is the SqlFilter, which implements a subset of SQL92.

trans-unit.source: SQL filters operate on the properties of the messages that are published to the topic.
trans-unit.target: SQL filters operate on the properties of the messages that are published to the topic.

trans-unit.source: For more information about SqlFilters, see <link><linkText>SqlFilter.SqlExpression Property[sqlfilter]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about SqlFilters, see <link><linkText>SqlFilter.SqlExpression Property[sqlfilter]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Each rule on a subscription processes incoming messages independently, adding their result messages to the subscription.
trans-unit.target: Each rule on a subscription processes incoming messages independently, adding their result messages to the subscription.

trans-unit.source: In addition, each new subscription has a default Rule object with a filter that adds all messages from the topic to the subscription.
trans-unit.target: In addition, each new subscription has a default Rule object with a filter that adds all messages from the topic to the subscription.

trans-unit.source: To receive only messages matching your filter, you must remove the default rule.
trans-unit.target: To receive only messages matching your filter, you must remove the default rule.

trans-unit.source: You can remove the default rule by using the ServiceBusRestProxy->deleteRule method.
trans-unit.target: You can remove the default rule by using the ServiceBusRestProxy->deleteRule method.

trans-unit.source: The following example creates a subscription named HighMessages with a SqlFilter that only selects messages that have a custom MessageNumber property greater than 3 (see How to: Send messages to a topic for information about adding custom properties to messages):
trans-unit.target: The following example creates a subscription named HighMessages with a SqlFilter that only selects messages that have a custom MessageNumber property greater than 3 (see How to: Send messages to a topic for information about adding custom properties to messages):

trans-unit.source: Note that the code above requires the use of an additional namespace: WindowsAzure\ServiceBus\Models\SubscriptionInfo.
trans-unit.target: Note that the code above requires the use of an additional namespace: WindowsAzure\ServiceBus\Models\SubscriptionInfo.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, the following example creates a subscription named LowMessages with a SqlFilter that only selects messages that have a MessageNumber property less than or equal to 3:
trans-unit.target: Similarly, the following example creates a subscription named LowMessages with a SqlFilter that only selects messages that have a MessageNumber property less than or equal to 3:

trans-unit.source: Now, when a message is sent to the mytopic topic, it is always delivered to receivers subscribed to the mysubscription subscription, and selectively delivered to receivers subscribed to the HighMessages and LowMessages subscriptions (depending upon the message content).
trans-unit.target: Now, when a message is sent to the mytopic topic, it is always delivered to receivers subscribed to the mysubscription subscription, and selectively delivered to receivers subscribed to the HighMessages and LowMessages subscriptions (depending upon the message content).

trans-unit.source: How to: send messages to a topic
trans-unit.target: How to: send messages to a topic

trans-unit.source: To send a message to a Service Bus topic, your application calls the ServiceBusRestProxy->sendTopicMessage method.
trans-unit.target: To send a message to a Service Bus topic, your application calls the ServiceBusRestProxy->sendTopicMessage method.

trans-unit.source: The following code shows how to send a message to the mytopic topic previously created within the
trans-unit.target: The following code shows how to send a message to the mytopic topic previously created within the

trans-unit.source: MySBNamespace service namespace.
trans-unit.target: MySBNamespace service namespace.

trans-unit.source: Messages sent to Service Bus topics are instances of the BrokeredMessage class.
trans-unit.target: Messages sent to Service Bus topics are instances of the BrokeredMessage class.

trans-unit.source: BrokeredMessage objects have a set of standard properties and methods (such as getLabel, getTimeToLive, setLabel, and setTimeToLive), as well as properties that can be used to hold custom application-specific properties.
trans-unit.target: BrokeredMessage objects have a set of standard properties and methods (such as getLabel, getTimeToLive, setLabel, and setTimeToLive), as well as properties that can be used to hold custom application-specific properties.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to send 5 test messages to the mytopic topic previously created.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to send 5 test messages to the mytopic topic previously created.

trans-unit.source: The setProperty method is used to add a custom property (MessageNumber) to each message.
trans-unit.target: The setProperty method is used to add a custom property (MessageNumber) to each message.

trans-unit.source: Note that the MessageNumber property value varies on each message (you can use this value to determine which subscriptions receive it, as shown in the How to: Create a Subscription section):
trans-unit.target: Note that the MessageNumber property value varies on each message (you can use this value to determine which subscriptions receive it, as shown in the How to: Create a Subscription section):

trans-unit.source: Service Bus queues support a maximum message size of 256 KB (the header, which includes the standard and custom application properties, can have a maximum size of 64 KB).
trans-unit.target: Service Bus queues support a maximum message size of 256 KB (the header, which includes the standard and custom application properties, can have a maximum size of 64 KB).

trans-unit.source: There is no limit on the number of messages held in a queue but there is a cap on the total size of the messages held by a queue.
trans-unit.target: There is no limit on the number of messages held in a queue but there is a cap on the total size of the messages held by a queue.

trans-unit.source: This upper limit on queue size is 5 GB.
trans-unit.target: This upper limit on queue size is 5 GB.

trans-unit.source: How to: receive messages from a subscription
trans-unit.target: How to: receive messages from a subscription

trans-unit.source: The best way to receive messages from a subscription is to use a ServiceBusRestProxy->receiveSubscriptionMessage method.
trans-unit.target: The best way to receive messages from a subscription is to use a ServiceBusRestProxy->receiveSubscriptionMessage method.

trans-unit.source: Received messages can work in two different modes: ReceiveAndDelete (the default) and PeekLock.
trans-unit.target: Received messages can work in two different modes: ReceiveAndDelete (the default) and PeekLock.

trans-unit.source: When using the ReceiveAndDelete mode, receive is a single-shot operation - that is, when Service Bus receives a read request for a message in a subscription, it marks the message as being consumed and returns it to the application.
trans-unit.target: When using the ReceiveAndDelete mode, receive is a single-shot operation - that is, when Service Bus receives a read request for a message in a subscription, it marks the message as being consumed and returns it to the application.

trans-unit.source: ReceiveAndDelete mode is the simplest model and works best for scenarios in which an
trans-unit.target: ReceiveAndDelete mode is the simplest model and works best for scenarios in which an

trans-unit.source: application can tolerate not processing a message in the event of a failure.
trans-unit.target: application can tolerate not processing a message in the event of a failure.

trans-unit.source: To understand this, consider a scenario in which the consumer issues the receive request and then crashes before processing it.
trans-unit.target: To understand this, consider a scenario in which the consumer issues the receive request and then crashes before processing it.

trans-unit.source: Because Service Bus will have marked the message as being consumed, then when the application restarts and begins consuming messages again, it will have missed the message that was consumed prior to the crash.
trans-unit.target: Because Service Bus will have marked the message as being consumed, then when the application restarts and begins consuming messages again, it will have missed the message that was consumed prior to the crash.

trans-unit.source: In PeekLock mode, receiving a message becomes a two stage operation, which makes it possible to support applications that cannot tolerate missing messages.
trans-unit.target: In PeekLock mode, receiving a message becomes a two stage operation, which makes it possible to support applications that cannot tolerate missing messages.

trans-unit.source: When Service Bus receives a request, it finds the next message to be consumed, locks it to prevent other consumers receiving it, and then returns it to the application.
trans-unit.target: When Service Bus receives a request, it finds the next message to be consumed, locks it to prevent other consumers receiving it, and then returns it to the application.

trans-unit.source: After the application finishes processing the message (or stores it reliably for future processing), it completes the second stage of the receive process by passing the received message to ServiceBusRestProxy->deleteMessage.
trans-unit.target: After the application finishes processing the message (or stores it reliably for future processing), it completes the second stage of the receive process by passing the received message to ServiceBusRestProxy->deleteMessage.

trans-unit.source: When Service Bus sees the deleteMessage call, it will mark the message as being consumed and remove it from the queue.
trans-unit.target: When Service Bus sees the deleteMessage call, it will mark the message as being consumed and remove it from the queue.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how a message can be received and processed using PeekLock mode (not the default mode).
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how a message can be received and processed using PeekLock mode (not the default mode).

trans-unit.source: How to: handle application crashes and unreadable messages
trans-unit.target: How to: handle application crashes and unreadable messages

trans-unit.source: Service Bus provides functionality to help you gracefully recover from errors in your application or difficulties processing a message.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus provides functionality to help you gracefully recover from errors in your application or difficulties processing a message.

trans-unit.source: If a receiver application is unable to process the message for some reason, then it can call the unlockMessage method on the received message (instead of the deleteMessage method).
trans-unit.target: If a receiver application is unable to process the message for some reason, then it can call the unlockMessage method on the received message (instead of the deleteMessage method).

trans-unit.source: This will cause Service Bus to unlock the message within the queue and make it available to be received again, either by the same consuming application or by another consuming application.
trans-unit.target: This will cause Service Bus to unlock the message within the queue and make it available to be received again, either by the same consuming application or by another consuming application.

trans-unit.source: There is also a timeout associated with a message locked within the queue, and if the application fails to process the message before the lock timeout expires (for example, if the application crashes), then Service Bus will unlock the message automatically and make it available to be received again.
trans-unit.target: There is also a timeout associated with a message locked within the queue, and if the application fails to process the message before the lock timeout expires (for example, if the application crashes), then Service Bus will unlock the message automatically and make it available to be received again.

trans-unit.source: In the event that the application crashes after processing the message but before the deleteMessage request is issued, then the message will be redelivered to the application when it restarts.
trans-unit.target: In the event that the application crashes after processing the message but before the deleteMessage request is issued, then the message will be redelivered to the application when it restarts.

trans-unit.source: This is often called At Least Once Processing; that is, each message is processed at least once but in certain situations the same message may be redelivered.
trans-unit.target: This is often called At Least Once Processing; that is, each message is processed at least once but in certain situations the same message may be redelivered.

trans-unit.source: If the scenario cannot tolerate duplicate processing, then application developers should add additional logic to applications to handle duplicate message delivery.
trans-unit.target: If the scenario cannot tolerate duplicate processing, then application developers should add additional logic to applications to handle duplicate message delivery.

trans-unit.source: This is often achieved using the getMessageId method of the message, which remains constant across delivery attempts.
trans-unit.target: This is often achieved using the getMessageId method of the message, which remains constant across delivery attempts.

trans-unit.source: How to delete topics and subscriptions
trans-unit.target: How to delete topics and subscriptions

trans-unit.source: To delete a topic or a subscription, use the ServiceBusRestProxy->deleteTopic or the ServiceBusRestProxy->deleteSubscripton methods, respectively.
trans-unit.target: To delete a topic or a subscription, use the ServiceBusRestProxy->deleteTopic or the ServiceBusRestProxy->deleteSubscripton methods, respectively.

trans-unit.source: Note that deleting a topic also deletes any subscriptions that are registered with the topic.
trans-unit.target: Note that deleting a topic also deletes any subscriptions that are registered with the topic.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to delete a topic (mytopic) and its registered subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to delete a topic (mytopic) and its registered subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: By using the deleteSubscription method, you can delete a subscription independently:
trans-unit.target: By using the deleteSubscription method, you can delete a subscription independently:
